awd_titl_txt: CCSS: Collaborative Research: Smart-Grid Powered Green Communications in Heterogeneous Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Both the current wireless communication networks and the electricity grid infrastructure are on the verge of a major paradigm shift. The traditional cellular architecture is evolving into heterogeneous networks (HetNets) consisting of densely deployed macro/micro/pico-cell base stations (BSs). In such HetNets, coordinated transmissions are advocated to perform energy-efficient green communications. At the same time, the current power network infrastructure is also migrating toward a so-termed smart grid that promises unprecedented levels of monitorability and controllability. It is expected that all future communication systems will be powered by a smart grid. Integration of smart-grid technologies into system designs then holds the key to fully exploiting the potential of green communications in next-generation HetNets. This highlights the clear need for fundamental understanding and systematic exploration of smart-grid powered green communications in HetNet deployments.

To this end, the present project is centered on transformative analytical and algorithmic tools for smart-grid powered green communications. The vision is to establish a comprehensive framework based on state-of-the-art optimization approaches to jointly design green HetNets along with critically relevant smart grid operations. By cross-fertilizing ideas between these two fields, the ultimate goal is to set forth a unified treatment for modeling, analyzing, and designing resource management schemes for smart-grid powered HetNets. The engineering outcome of the proposed research is a suite of protocols for distributed, real-time implementation of basestation activation, coordinated beamforming in HetNets, as well as renewable energy harvesting and storage, demand response, and unit commitment operations for smart grids. Creating energy-efficient, distributed, real-time algorithms will greatly enhance the performance of emerging wireless cellular networks while reducing carbon emissions and enhancing the green communication solution to climate change and global warming. This project also addresses the broader impacts of improving undergraduate STEM education, increasing participation of under-represented minorities, and promoting a scientifically literate public.

1. Beacon-assisted wireless-powered communications in Nakagami fading environments

In many wireless applications, the wireless devices and sensors are usually powered through rechargeable batteries with limited and batteries must be frequently plugged into the power grid or replaced, limiting the operational lifetime of the devices and increasing the cost of service, and diminishing user experience and quality of service. In wireless sensor networks and internet of things (IoT) applications, due to their massive deployment and physical limitations, replacing or recharging the batteries are not always possible. To overcome the energy limitation problem, energy harvesting techniques have been used to harness energy from external environmental sources including radio frequency (RF) sources, which can provide stable energy supply and enhance lifetime of energy-constrained wireless devices and sensors, even when the devices are at long distances from the power sources because RF signals can simultaneously carry energy and information signals. A dedicated power beacon or a cluster of power beacons may be deployed around the access points to enhance the energy harvesting capability of the transmitters.

Traditionally, a “harvest-then-transmit” communication protocol is adopted that uses a fraction of the available symbol time or power for energy harvesting from the power beacons and the remaining time or power used by the source for data transmission to the destination. Thus, in time-switching schemes, a fraction τ (where 0<τ<1) of the transmission time of T symbols is used for energy harvesting from the power beacons while (1-τ) of T is used for the source to transmit data to the destination. In practice, a preset value of the fraction τ is usually chosen to optimize the system throughput. In this work, we take a different approach and  choose τ randomly from a beta distribution. By using a gamma approximation to the aggregate interference, closed-form expressions are derived for the outage probability and average capacity that accounts for the randomness of τ and its effect of the interfering signals.  Our analysis and numerical results show that randomizing the time-switching parameter provides a meaninful alternative approach that may advance wireless-powered communications.

 

2. Ergodic capacity of generalized fading channels in the presence of user mobility

Channel capacity is an important performance metric in conventional and emerging wireless communication systems. The most widely used measure of capacity is the ergodic channel capacity (ECC), which is the maximum transmission rate that is attainable over a bandlimited channel, when the transmit power is fixed and the channel state information (CSI) is known to the receiver. In the presence of fading and shadowing, the ergodic channel capacity is available in the literature for many commonly encountered fading/shadowing environments. However, in the presence of user mobility, which is present in most wireless communication networks, the effect of user mobility on receiver performance is not so readily available.  

In this work, the impact of user mobility on the ECC of wireless receivers that experience fading, shadowing, and path loss is evaluated for the RWP mobility model. We consider the random waypoint (RWP) mobility model, which has been frequently used in wireless scenarios where the nodes move independently to a randomly chosen destination with a randomly selected velocity, the wireless receiver location varies randomly as the mobile terminal moves randomly in the service area. Then using analytical expressions obtained from the literature for ECC for static fading channel models, we provide analytical expressions for the exact and asymptotic ergodic capacities ifor the wireless receiver with user mobility under several generalized fading conditions. In the high SNR regime, the ECC in the mobile case may be expressed in terms of the ECC in the static case, evaluated for the SNR at the edge of the coverage area, plus a term that depends on the RWP model parameters and the path loss coefficient and is independent of the fading parameters.
